text: Philip Parris "Phil" Lynott (20 August 1949 â€“ 4 January 1986) was an Irish musician. He was born in West Bromwich, Staffordshire, England and raised in Dublin, Ireland from age four. His mother was businesswoman Philomena Lynott. He was a bass guitar player and singer. He was the leader of the rock band Thin Lizzy. Lynott started Thin Lizzy in 1969. He also made two solo albums in the early 1980s. Thin Lizzy were famous for their songs "The Boys Are Back in Town", "Waiting for an Alibi", "Whisky in the Jar" and "Jailbreak". Lynott also worked with Gary Moore. Lynott had problems with drugs and alcohol in his final years. On 25 December 1985, he collapsed and went to a clinic in Wiltshire, England. He was diagnosed with septicaemia. He died of pneumonia and heart failure in Salisbury, Wiltshire on 4 January 1986. He was 36. ==References== ==Other websites== * Category:1949 births Category:1986 deaths Category:Bass guitarists Category:Deaths from heart failure Category:Deaths from pneumonia Category:Deaths from sepsis Category:Infectious disease deaths in England Category:Irish guitarists Category:Irish rock musicians Category:Irish singer-songwriters Category:Musicians from Dublin Category:Musicians from Staffordshire
title: Phil Lynott
